\section{Introduction}

The problem of similarity search in high-dimensional datasets has been a challenging problem in computer science for many years. The problem arises in various applications such as data mining, bioinformatics, and recommendation systems. In these applications, the goal is to find the most similar data points in a large dataset, which can be used for various purposes such as clustering, classification, and recommendation.

The problem becomes more challenging when the dataset is ultra-high dimensional, which means that the number of features is much larger than the number of data points. In such cases, traditional similarity search algorithms, such as k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) and cosine similarity, become inefficient due to the curse of dimensionality.

To address this problem, we propose a novel similarity search algorithm called FLASH (Fast LSH-based Algorithm for Similarity search accelerated with HPC), which is based on the concept of Locally Sparse Hashing (LSH). LSH is a technique that allows for efficient similarity search in high-dimensional spaces by reducing the search space to a much smaller one.

FLASH is designed to be efficient and scalable for ultra-high dimensional datasets. It uses a combination of LSH and a novel hashing technique called "hashing with random projections" (HRP) to reduce the search space to a much smaller one. The algorithm is also designed to be parallelizable, which means that it can be executed on a cluster of machines, allowing for faster execution times.

The first filial generation of the backcross breeding program is the F1 generation. The F1 generation is the result of crossing two different inbred lines, one tall and one dwarf, to produce a population of F1 hybrid plants. These F1 hybrid plants are then backcrossed to the tall parent line to produce a new cultivar that is genetically similar to the tall parent line but has the desired dwarf phenotype. This process can take many years and requires many backcrosses to produce a new cultivar that is genetically similar to the tall parent line but has the desired dwarf phenotype.
